questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

questions.text: Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022) Nocardia Mycobacterium leprae Actinomyces Cryptosporidium parvum Isospora belli
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to you with neuropathy in his bilateral lower limbs and a positive Romberg sign. He has a history of gastrectomy for stomach cancer. He is likely deficient in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-gastrectomy patients are at high risk for Vitamin B12 deficiency due to lack of intrinsic factor production, leading to neurological manifestations like peripheral neuropathy, positive Romberg sign and megaloblastic anemia. Lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation is essential in such patients to prevent neurological and hematological complications.
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • ➤ peripheral neuropathy, positive Romberg sign and megaloblastic anemia. Lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation is essential in such patients to prevent neurological and hematological complications.
  • ➤ Causes of B12 Deficiency
  • ➤ Causes of B12 Deficiency
  • ➤ Vegans At stomach level - Elderly/ gastrectomy / Pernicious anemia At pancreas level - Pancreatitis, hypofunctioning pancreas At intestine level - Bacterial overgrowth syndrome, diverticulosis. At ileum level - Malabsorption disorders, GIT TB, Crohn's disease, fish tapeworm ↓ intake ↓ absorption - ↓ intrinsic factor – pernicious anemia ↑ requirement - Children, pregnancy, lactation
  • ➤ Vegans
  • ➤ At stomach level - Elderly/ gastrectomy / Pernicious anemia
  • ➤ At pancreas level - Pancreatitis, hypofunctioning pancreas
  • ➤ At intestine level - Bacterial overgrowth syndrome, diverticulosis.
  • ➤ At ileum level - Malabsorption disorders, GIT TB, Crohn's disease, fish tapeworm
  • ➤ ↓ intake
  • ➤ ↓ absorption - ↓ intrinsic factor – pernicious anemia
  • ➤ ↑ requirement - Children, pregnancy, lactation

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of action of vancomycin as shown in the image below
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vancomycin acts at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, thereby inhibiting further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

options.label: B
options.text: Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.correct_answer: A. Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.
  • • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.
  • • Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia:
  • • Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.
  • • Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia:
  • • Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:
  • • Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:
  • • Angiogenic Factors:
  • • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng) Factors that are decreased are PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
  • • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Factors that are decreased are PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • PlGF
  • • PAPP-A
  • • VEGF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region . It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.
  • • sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region
  • • The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.
  • • The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) : The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII)
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? ( INICET May 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrease generation of reduced glutathione
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.

  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 185-186

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, acute diarrhea, and is diagnosed with celiac disease. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: IgA Tissue Transglutaminase antibodies are present

options.label: D
options.text: IgG deamidated Gliadin antibodies are present

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Associated with HLA DQ6/DQ11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6/DQ11, and diagnosis involves IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies, deamidated gliadin antibodies, and application of the Marsh criteria.
  • ➤ Important disease associated with HLA
  • ➤ Important disease associated with HLA

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma , with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • ➤ Mollicutes
  • ➤ Mycoplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma urealyticum

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for long term management of obesity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Liraglutide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liraglutide is a viable and approved option for the long-term management of obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1 to help regulate appetite and reduce calorie intake. Other Options like sibutramine and fenfluramine have been withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, and metformin, while causing modest weight loss, is not primarily indicated for obesity treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.
  • ➤ Beta 1, 3, glucan

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oocysts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110 mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thrombolysis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute ischemic stroke with BP < 185/110 and clear NCCT, thrombolysis is the next step.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: B
options.text: Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: C
options.text: Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase. Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • ➤ H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • ➤ Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ 1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)
  • ➤ 2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)
  • ➤ Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.
  • ➤ Refsum's disease:
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • ➤ In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.correct_answer: C. Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range. Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes: Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels. Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • ➤ Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation:
  • ➤ Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes: Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Increase in Blood Calcium:
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream. Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body. Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
  • ➤ Stimulation of Osteoclasts:
  • ➤ Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
  • ➤ Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption:
  • ➤ Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • ➤ Activation of Vitamin D:
  • ➤ Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.
  • ➤ Negative Feedback Loop:

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

questions.text: Dorzolamide is a: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor, making it effective in the treatment of glaucoma. This distinguishes it from sulfonamide antibacterials, second-generation sulfonylureas, and opioid receptor agonists, which are used for different medical conditions.

options.label: A

options.label: B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Box and Whisker plot
  • ➤ Box and Whisker plot
  • ➤ A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles. It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides. The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3) The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution. The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.
  • ➤ A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • ➤ It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • ➤ The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • ➤ The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • ➤ The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • ➤ The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: In Decompression sickness, which one of the following is not seen? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hemodilution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decompression sickness causes hemoconcentration (not hemodilution) due to plasma extravasation resulting from vascular damage caused by nitrogen bubbles.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? ( INICET Nov 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

options.label: B
options.text: The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible

options.label: C
options.text: They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design

options.label: D
options.text: The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.correct_answer: A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CLINICAL IMPORTANCE
  • ➤ CLINICAL IMPORTANCE
  • ➤ Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.
  • ➤ Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.
  • ➤ EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS
  • ➤ EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS
  • ➤ Beta lactams (Penicillins) Aspirin Allopurinol MAO inhibitors
  • ➤ Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • ➤ Aspirin
  • ➤ Allopurinol
  • ➤ MAO inhibitors

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.correct_answer: A. Short arm of Y chromosome
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.
  • • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.
  • • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.
  • • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.
  • • Y- chromosome
  • • The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.
  • • Option B) Short arm of X chromosome:
  • • Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.
  • • Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome:
  • • Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.
  • • Option D) Long arm of X chromosome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: ( INICET Nov 2020) Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  • ➤ Cochlear Nucleus
  • ➤ Superior Olivary nucleus
  • ➤ Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ Auditory cortex
  • ➤ The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pap smear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:
  • • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix. Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample. Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample. Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively. Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.
  • • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum:
  • • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • • Koplin's jar:
  • • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • • Slides to prepare the smear:
  • • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush:
  • • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.
  • • Fixative containing 95% ethanol:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.
  • • Option B. Hysteroscopy:
  • • Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.
  • • Option C. Biopsy:
  • • Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.
  • • Option D. Dilatation and curettage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition 632, 633
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1

options.label: B
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

options.label: C
options.text: A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin

options.label: D
options.text: A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH) : Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH)
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH) : GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH)
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH) : GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH)
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1) : IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1)
  • • The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.
  • ➤ Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma):
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma:
  • • Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.
  • • Option D. Renal cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:

  • ➤ Glutathione Peroxidase

  • ➤ Iodothyronine deiodinase

  • ➤ Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • ➤ This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024) Bemepedoic acid Ezetimibe Gemfibrozil Evolocumab
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:
  • • 1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis
  • • Bempedoic
  • • 2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption
  • • Ezetimibe
  • • 4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.
  • • Evolocumab
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • 3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).
  • • 3. Gemfibrozil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urine Ca

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid

options.label: C
options.text: Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.correct_answer: A. It is exclusively given in the deltoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.
  • ➤ Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 441
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 441
